justification: In Study 1 the author states that “trait mindfulness, assessed by the Mindful Awareness Attention Scale (MAAS, which focuses on present-moment awareness, Brown & Ryan, 2003)” was examined.
The literature review notes that “the observing facet of mindfulness (assessed by the Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire, Baer et al., 2006) was associated with better perceptual abilities.”

The same sentence contrasts that “the nonjudgmental facet of mindfulness was associated with better cognitive control,” implying that this facet—like the observing facet—is taken from the FFMQ assessment.

measured_by: Resistance to Sunk Costs subscale of the Adult Decision Making Competence index (RSC)
justification: The methods section explains that participants’ willingness to continue was “measured using… the Resistance to Sunk Costs subscale of the Adult Decision Making Competence index (RSC, Bruine, Parker, & Fischhoff, 2007).”

measured_by: average rating across Sunk-cost Fallacy Questionnaire (SCFQ) scenarios
justification: For Study 1, the author notes that “the participants' average rating across the sixteen SCFQ scenarios… was used as a measure of escalation of commitment.”

The SCFQ is described as presenting paired high- and low-investment scenarios so that “participants… are considered to be susceptible to the sunk-cost fallacy,” establishing it as a measure of the sunk-cost bias.

measured_by: printing press and airplane scenarios (Arkes & Blumer, 1985)
justification: In Study 3 participants completed “the printing press and airplane scenarios of Arkes and Blumer (1985)” specifically to test susceptibility to sunk-costs after the mindfulness induction.
